UseofUltrasonography VersusMagnetic Resonance ImagingforTendon
Abnormalities AroundtheAnkle
Matthew S. Rockett, D.P.M.,* Gayle Waitches, D.O.,tGarySudakoff, M.D.,:f:and Michael Brage, M.D.§
Houston, Texas,Seattle, Washington, and Chicago, Illinois
ABSTRACT
Aprospective studywasperformed on 28patientswho
underwent surgeryfortendondisorders aroundthean­
kle.Preoperatively, allpatients hadreal-time, highreso­
lutionultrasonography performed witha 7.5or10mHz
transducer. Twentyofthesepatients alsohad apreop­
erativemagnetic resonance imaging (MRI)examination
oftheankle.Atotalof54tendons wereinspected intra­
operatively, revealing atotalof24intrasubstance or
complete tendontears.Thesesurgical findings were
compared withtheultrasound and MRI findings, from
whichthesensitivity, specificity, andaccuracy werecal­
culatedforbothmodalities. Ultrasound produced results
withasensitivity measurement of100%,specificity of
89.9%, and accuracy of94.4%. MRI produced results
withasensitivity measurement of23.4%,specificity of
100%, and accuracy of65.75%.Ultrasound resultswere
moresensitive andaccurate thanMRI inthedetection of
ankletendontearsinourstudy.
INTRODUCTION
Plainweightbearing and stress radiographs of the
foot and ankle are often the first diagnostic modalities
used in the patientwithankle pain. Plain radiographs
can assess angular abnormalities of thefootand ankle
(acquired pes planus and lateral ankle instabil­
ity),19,20,38,42 fractureof aradiographic osperoneum
(peroneus longus tear),30,43 or anyothergrossosse­
ousabnormalities. Iftheclinicalandradiographic find­
ingsindicateapossible tendonabnormality, or the

604diagnosis is inquestion, anotherdiagnostic modality
istypically used for confirmation the diagnosis.
Tenography, 1,17,18,19computed tomography,32,31-34,40
ultrasonography 6,11,27,39,41, andmagnetic resonance
imaging (MRI) 2,3,7,24,31,33,35,36,38,44,45 have been used
in thedetection of ankletendontears. Currently, MRI
isconsidered to be the imaging modality ofchoicein
thedetection of ankle tendon abnormali­
ties.2,3,7,24,35,36,44 In ourexperience at a large univer-
sitymedicalcenter, MRI has been less than accurate
indetecting intrasubstance andcomplete ankle ten­
don tears. Therefore, weundertook a search for a
moresensitive modality.
Ultrasound of the ankle to detecttendonabnor­
malities has been an underused modality, except
forpathologic condition of the Achilles ten­
don.5,14,21,22,25,29 Although ultrasound isincreasingly
being used for the diagnosis ofmusculoskeletal ab­
normalities in the shoulder, knee, and hand,4,9,13-16,23
use for ankle tendondisorders has been limited.

6,11,14,27,28,39,41 Ourpurpose, in this article, is to de-
scribethe use of ultrasonography for the imaging of
pathologic conditions of ankletendonsand to present
aprospective comparison between ultrasound and
MRI.
MATERIALS AND METHODS
Aprospective studywasperformed on 28patients
who were examined between October1995 and June
1996, with clinical symptoms suggestive of tears of
the peroneal or tibialisposterior tendons. All 28 pa­
tientssubsequently underwent anultrasound exami­
nation of the ankle. Twentyof the 28 patientsalso
underwent MRIof the ankle region to ruleout atendon
abnormality. All 28patientsunderwent surgery when
nonoperative treatments were found to be ineffective.
Operative findingswere used as the gold standard for
determining theeffectiveness of bothdiagnostic mo­
dalities.
Ultrasound of the ankle tendonswasperformed by
tworadiologists who were familiarwithmusculoskel-

Foot&Ankle InternationallVol. 19,No.9/September 1998 USE OF IMAGING FOR TENDON ABNORMALITIES 605
etaIultrasound examination, using a real-time, high
resolution ultrasound transducer. Thefollowing proto­
col was used:the patient wasfirst interviewed, andthe
clinical problem and the pointof maximal tenderness
wereelicited. Thetendon, or tendons, inquestion was
scanned with a commercially available ultrasound unit
(ATLUltramark 9-HDI, Bothwell, WA, or the Siemens
Elegra, Issaquah, WA), which had a 7.5 mHz linear
arrayand/ora broad band linear array 7.5-10.0 mHz
transducer, in the longitudinal andtransverse planes.
The patient was placed in the left or right posterior
oblique position, with a towel or pillowsupporting the
ankle.
On the lateral side of the ankle, the peroneal ten­
dons were scanned with the following technique: the
examination started 7to 8cm superiorto the tip of the
lateral malleolus. The tendons were then scanned
from the supramalleolar positionalong the course of
thetendonseither to the insertion on the fifth meta­
tarsal base (peroneus brevis) or until the tendon
coursed plantar to the cuboid(peroneus longus). To
ensurethatthetendonwasproperly identified as ei­
ther the peroneus brevis or peroneus longus, the ra­
diologistplaced the foot and ankle throughopen chain
kineticmovements. For the peroneus brevis, the foot
was initially placed in a neutral position, and the su­
pramalleolar portions of thetendons werelocated.
The foot was then everted and inverted by the exam­
iner, with the transducer visualizing the tendons in a
real-time mode. This motioncauses the peroneus bre­
vis to slide within its tendon sheath upon alternating
between eversion and inversion of the foot, whereas
the peroneus longus remained relatively staticduring
the maneuver. The peroneus longus is identified by
plantarflexion anddorsiflexion of the first metatarsal at
the first metatarsal cuneiform joint. The longus tendon
was visualized gliding within its tendonsheath on the
ultrasound image, whereas the brevis tendonre­
mained static. Each tendonwas then examined in
both thelongitudinal and transverse planes for abnor­
malities.
Onthe medial side ofthe ankle,the tibialisposterior
and flexor digitorum longus (FDL) tendons were
scanned according to the same protocol. Thetibialis
posterior tendonwas scanned from 8 to 10 ern supe­
rior to the medial malleolus to its insertion at the
navicular tuberosity. The FDL tendonwas examined
down to the level of the master knot of Henry. The
tibialisposterior isidentified inafashion similar to that
of the peroneal tendons. The footis placed in the
neutral position and then is inverted and plantarflexed.
Thismovement effectively creates a glidingmotionof
the tendon within its sheath. For the FDL tendon, thelesserdigitsaresimplyflexed and extended for iden­
tification of the tendon.
If anytendonabnormalities were noted, the area
was rescanned at multipledifferent angles, in an at­
temptto ensure thattheabnormalities were not arti­
factual. The presence, location, and extentof any
tendonpathologic condition wasrecorded for clinical
and surgical correlation. Thecontralateral limb was
then also scanned, using the same protocolfor use as
acomparison with thesymptomatic ankle.
MRI of the ankle was performed on 20 of the 28
patients.

MRI of the ankle was performed on 20 of the 28
patients. Fiveof the remaining eight patientshadcon­
traindications for theexamination (twopatients ex­
ceeded the MRI weightcapacity, one had a ferrous
metalobjectnear the spine, one was claustrophobic,
and one hadacranial aneurysmal clip).The otherthree
patients refused the MRI examination. MRI images
wereobtained in the coronal, sagittal, and axial im­
ages,according to thestandard protocol for ankle
tendondisorders at theUniversity ofChicago Hospi­
tals. A 1.5-Tesla extremity coil (General Electric, Mil­
waukee, WI)was used for the MRIimages. The image­
sequencing protocol included a2-mmcollimation, a
OA-mminterslice gap, T1- and T2-weighted oblique
sagittal images, and T2 fat suppression coronal and
axialobliqueimages. Five of the 20 patientshad ex­
aminations performed at anoutsideinstitution with
similarprotocols. All MRI films were interpreted by a
dedicated musculoskeletal radiologist.
Intraoperatively, the presence or absence, location,
andextentof anytendontears were noted. Intraoper­
ativephotographs wereobtained for allexposed ten­
dons for the purposes of the study. The surgical find­
ings were then compared with theultrasound and MRI
findings, from which the sensitivity, specificity, and
accuracy werecalculated for both ultrasonography
and MRI.26
RESULTS
Thestudypopulation included 20female and 8male
patientsranging inagefrom 21to 78years (meanage,
46.5 years).The average durationofsymptomatology
was 18.5 months(range,1-120months). All 28 pa­
tientsunderwent surgery. Intraoperatively, the pres­
ence,location, andextentof anytendontears were
noted on a total of 54 tendons. The results of each
individual patientandtendonis listed in Tables 1 and
2. Of the 20 patientswho had both ultrasonography
and MRI, a total of 38 tendons(9 tibialis posterior, 8
FDL, 10peroneus brevis, 10 peroneus longus, and 1
extensor hallucis longus tendon) were visualized atthe
time of surgery. Seventeen of these 38 tendons re­
vealed some form of tendontear (16intrasubstance

ultrasound, atotal of 16 tendons(6tibialisposterior, 3
peroneus brevis, 3 peroneus longus, and 4 FDL ten­
dons) were visualized intraoperatively, with 7 of these
tendons revealing a tear (all intrasubstance) of the
tendon in question. Allintrasubstance tears were
greater than 1cm inlength and were grosslyvisible on
inspection of the tendon.
MRIdetected 4 of 17surgically provedtendontears
andcorrectly identified all 21 normal tendons. Ultra­
sounddiagnosed all 17tendontears, while identifying
18 of 21 normal tendons. Thesensitivity, specificity,
andaccuracy for these 20 patientswere then calcu­
lated. For MRI, the sensitivity was23.4%,thespeci­
ficity 100%, and the accuracy 65.75%. Ultrasonogra­
phy, in the patients who had an MRI, showed a
sensitivity of100%,aspecificity of89.9%,and an
accuracy of 94.41%. In eight patientswho had only
ultrasound performed, ultrasound detected all eight
torntendonsand recorded seven of eight normal ten­
dons. The sensitivity, specificity, andaccuracy for the

Inaddition, thelocationof thetendontears was cor­
rectlyidentified 100%of the time in the true positive
results on scans for both ultrasonography and MRI.
DISCUSSION
Whenindicated, thecurrentliterature recommends
MRI for the detection oftendonabnormalities around
the ankle. Numerous authors haveemphasized
the merits of this modality and itsimportance for
preoperative planning for repair of the ankle ten­
dons. 2,3,7,24,33,35,36,44 Asensitivity of 95%, a specific-
ity of100%,and anaccuracy of96%have been
reported for MRI in the detection oftibialisposterior
tendontears.33Sarnrnarco'" reported apositiveresult
on MRI in eight of nine ruptured peroneus longus
tendonsthatwere repaired.

MRI can distinguish per­
onealtendonitis fromlongitudinal tendonsplits, as
shown in a studygroupof fourpatlents.r' Recently,
Khoury et al. 24reported on 12 patients, all of whom
had MRI examinations forpossible peroneal tendon
tears. MRI correctly identified 12tendontears with
twofalsepositiveresults and onefalse negative result.
Theauthorsofthe present studyhave notfoundthe
samesensitivity andaccuracy that has been reported
for MRI, even with the use of a 1.5-Tesla surface coil.
Forthis reason, we soughtanotherdiagnostic modal­
ity for the detection of ankletendontears. A review of
theliterature revealed only twocomparison studiesof
ultrasonography and MRI. One involved examination
ofpatellartendinitis, and the other reported on exam­
ination of the tibialisposterior tendon.Davies et al."
examined 16 cases of patellar tendinitis with ultra­
sonography, computed tomography, and MRI. They
found that all three modalities were equally effective,
and they recommended thatultrasound be used as
the initial investigative modality inpatientswith this
condition. Miller et al.27described the use of ultra-

608ROCKETT ET AL. Foot&AnkleInternationallVo/. 19,No.9/September 1998
Fig. 1. A, Longitudinal and B,transverse ultrasound images of the asymptomatic ankle of patient 1,which revealnormal peroneal tendons.
The normal tendon demostrates fine parallel echoic lines on the longitudinal image (arrows)and uniform echoic dots in a round configuration
(arrows)on the transverse image.
sound in tibialis posterior tendonabnormalities in 17
patients with surgically proved tears. Three of the
patients had MRI studies performed, with two of the
studies revealing no tendontear.
Normaltendons produce a low signal intensity
and appear homogeneously black on both T1- and
T2-weighted MRI images. T1-weighted images'pro­
videbetteranatomic detail, whereas T2-weighted
images provide additional information about the pres­
ence orabsence offluid, hemorrhage, oredema within
or around the tendon. The synovial sheath around the
tendoncannot be separated visually from the tendon
substance itself and will be seenonly asablack rim on
MRI when distended by synovial fluid.2,3
Tendonabnormalities, asseenon MRI,vary accord­
ingto the extent of the pathologic condition. Tenosyn­
ovitis will appear as an intermediate signalintensity
within the sheath on T1-weighted images and as a
high signal intensity onT2-weighted images. The
presence of this signal within the sheath has been
shown to be less effectively diagnostic for tendon
tears than was previously thought. Small volumes of
fluid have been shown to be normally present when
asymptomatic ankles were studiec.'" This fluid was
commonly seen at the distal aspectof the tendon,
caused by the gravitational effectwithin the tendon
sheath while the patient was in the supine position.
Intrasubstance tendontears appeared as focal areas
of signal hyperintensity within the tendonsubstance
on both T1- and T2-weighted images. A focal attenu­
ation orthickening of thetendonisusually seen inthishyperintense area because of the longitudinal nature
of thetendontear. The tendon sheath will be dis­
tended and is seen as linear areas of low signal inten­
sity separating the inflammatory fluid from the sur­
rounding fat. A complete disruption of the tendon will
typicallyreveal adiscontinuity, or gap, within the ten­
don substance. Thegap isusually hyperintense onT2,
caused by edema and hemorrhage. 3,24,33,36,44
On ultrasound, the normal tendon shows fine par­
allel echoic lines on the longitudinal images and
echoicdotsin an oval or round configuration on the
transverse images. These echogenic lines will be sur­
rounded by slightlyless echoic linesthat delineate the
tendonsheaths (Fig. 1 ).8,10,13,21 A small amount of
hypoechoic fluidsurrounding the tendon within the
sheath is normal, particularly distal to the rnalleoli.i"
Inthetendonsthat were read asabnormal on ultra­
sound in this study, we found that on the longitudinal
images (Fig. 2), there was a fusiform swelling of the
tendon at the area of the tear. The fine echoic parallel
linesof the tendonsweredisrupted, andahypoechoic
region was seenwithin thefusiform swelling.Typically,
surrounding this area there was a moderate-to-Iarge
amountofhypoechoic fluiddistending the tendon
sheath. Within this fluid, a varying amount of echo­
genic to hyperechoic material was commonly seen
outsidethe tendon substance, representing tendon
debris seen intraoperatively. This fusiform area was
then scanned in the transverse plane (Fig. 3). The
authors believe that transverse scanning is the keyto
the diagnosis of the intrasubstance tears.

Foot&Ankle International/Vol. 19,No.9/September 1998 USE OF IMAGING FORTENDON ABNORMALITIES 609
Fig. 2. Longitudinal ultrasound images of A,patient 1 and B,patient 11. Symptomatic ankles reveal a torn peroneus brevis and tibialis
posterior tendon, respectively. Note the fusiform swelling (arrows) at the site of the tear, with disruption of the parallelism and increased
hypoechoic regions. Also noted is the increased hypoechoic fluid and debris within the sheath.
The transverse scan again revealed a disruption of
the echoic architecture of the tendon. The most im­
portant finding was a hypoechoic line that extended
from the periphery of the tendon into the central ten­
don substance. This hypoechoic line had various
shapes and sizes, based on the size or length of the
tendon tears. In addition, the tendon was surrounded
by fluid of various amounts, with echoic debris. These
findings are regarding longitudinal orintrasubstance
tears. In patients who had atotal rupture, a complete
disruption of the fine echoic parallel lineswas evident,
with ahypoechoic gap between the ends of the rup­
tured tendon on both the longitudinal and transverse
ultrasound images.Atotal rupture also revealedatotal
absence of a gliding mechanism on active movement
of the tendon.
Based on the operative findingsand a review of the
corresponding ultrasound images, the authors have
divided the ultrasound findingsinto major and minor
criteria for tendon tears (Table 4). Major criteria aredefined as findingsnoted100%of the time in abnor­
maltendons, but not in normal tendons. Minor criteria
werefindingsthat were noted in torn tendons, but
could also be seeninnormal tendons. Inreviewing the
patients who had false positiveand true negative re­
sults, the authors determined that for a tendonto be
considered torn, the patients needed to have at least
two of the major criteria. Inpatients with false positive
results, only one or two of the minor criteria and none
of the major criteria were met.
Incomparing the results of the sensitivity andaccu­
racy ofultrasonography with the results of MRI, the
authors found a common factorthat led to the large
number of false negative results from MRI. In the
tendon tears that were identified as torn on both MRI
and surgery, the patients' histories showed that the
durationofsymptoms was relatively short, (meantime,
2.5months; range, 2-3months), whereas the false
negative results typicallyhadlongstanding symptoms
(mean30.5months; range, 3-120months). These

tendons isa hypoechoic linethat extends from the periphery into the tendon substance (solidarrows).The tendons areagain surrounded by
fluid with echoic debris (openarrows).

falsenegativeresultscan beattributed to the fact that
the MRI signal is based on the excitability of water
molecutes." Asthe injury becomes more chronic, the
water content within the injured tendon decreases,
secondary to fibrosis of the tendon and adecrease in
inflammation, which creates a decrease in the signal
on the MRI.
Thecomplaints ofthepatients with long-term symp­
toms were mostly secondary to adaptations that re­
sulted from the long-term weaknessofthetendon. For
example, patient 1 had injured his ankle 120 months
previously while performing karate, before presenting
with acomplaint of his ankle giving out when he ran
only a few meters. Hehad no notable ankle instability
at clinical or radiographic examination, but did havea
gross clinical weakness of the peroneus brevis. An
MRIexamination was performed that revealed no ab­
normality of the peronealtendons (Fig.4).Thesubse­
quent ultrasound revealed a longitudinal tear of the
peroneusbrevis(Figs.2and3A),which wasconfirmed
intraoperatively (Fig.5).
A common finding in patients who had symptoms
lasting more than eight months was minimal or no
inflammatous tissues surrounding the tendon tears. In
patients that had positive results on MRI,there was a
significant amount of synovitis and granulation tissue
within the tendon complex.
Advantages of ultrasonography compared with MRI
are that it is inexpensive, rapid, and widely avail­able.
27,41At our institution, the charge for ultrasonog­
raphy isfour times lessexpensive than for MRI.Ultra­
sound also has the advantage of being the only
dynamic interactive diagnostic modality of the ankle
tendons. The examiner can actively move the tendon
in question while performing the examination, and,
withthepatient'sinput,canelucidatetheareaoffocus
for the examination. Inaddition, because of the inter­
active nature of the ultrasound examination, the ten­
don can be visualized at multiple different angles and
planesso that any artifactual results are eliminated.V
The MRI examination is dependent entirely on the
one-time position of the foot for each plane scanned.
If the foot is not in the optimal position, an important
portion of the tendon may be visualized poony.'"Minor criteria
---------- ---------------------
Echoic or hyperechoic debris in sheath
Fusiform swelling without hypoechoic signal within the tendon
Hypoechoic signal surrounding tendon lessthan 1cm
Ultrasound isalsoableto detect moresubtleinjuries
in tendons than MRI, according to our observations.
For example, patient 20 had an MRI which showed
that the extensor hallucis longus was completely rup­
tured, but ultrasound revealed that the tendon was
torn only partially from the dorsal to the plantar posi­
tion, which was confirmed to be a partial rupture,
intraoperatively. Also, ultrasound can be used in thepresence of ferrous and metallic implants, as well aspacemakers, which are contraindicated for MRI use.
The disadvantage of ultrasonography is that it is
very operator- and machine-dependent. An inexperi­
enced ultrasonographer and/or the useof a low reso­
lutiontransducer can produce false negative results.
Fig. 4.T2-weightedMRI sagittal image of the peroneus brevis in
patient 1 showing no intrasubstance tear of the tendon.

REFERENCESThe authors believe that high resolution, real-time
ultrasound should be the first-linediagnostic modality
ofchoiceif aspecifictendontear around the ankle is
suspected. Ultrasound is more sensitive and accurate
than MRI in the detection of tendon tears around the
ankle. Inaddition, ultrasonography isfaster, morecost
effective, more widely available, and more interactive
than the MRI examination, withminimal-to-no patient
contraindications.

CONCLUSION
Fig. 5. Intraoperative photograph of the patient's peroneal ten­
dons demonstrates an intrasubstance rupture of the peroneus bre­
vis.
Also, if a high resolution transducer is used, and the
proper anatomic region is not scanned, a false nega­
tive result can occurbecause of the smallfocal areaof
thesetransducers.!" The major disadvantage of ultra­
sound, as compared with MRI,isthat itislimited inthe
anatomic detail of deeper tissues around the ankle,
and it is unable to image bone.27,41This issecondary
to the short focal length of the transducers needed to
image the tendons, as well as the blockage of sound
wavesthat bone produces. If more than just a tendon
tear issuspected, an MRI evaluation may be indi­
cated.
Our study was limited by the fact that it was neither
random norblind. Thesurgeons knew the diagnosis of
tendon tear before the surgery was to be performed,
and theradiologists were looking for a tendontear on
ultrasound. Further analysis is required in a random­
izeddouble-blind study.Foot&Ankle Internationai/Vo/. 19,No.9/September 1998
